instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP1V8_S5: What is PP1V8_S5? PP1V8_S5 is a 1.8v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state. .
definitions.820-01958: What is 820-01958? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> // Will not startup // <CHIP>U1200</CHIP> extreme heat
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that has no visible or accidental damage.

The symptoms were that the MacBook got really hot, shut down and will not turn back on.

I have inspected the board closely and have been unable to find any damage or short circuits. The when attempting to boot the board, it shows 20v in all ports with normal amp draw almost reaching 2.5A. (seems like it is booting). I tested voltages on CPU lines and CPU power supplies and everything appears normal.

T2 Revive completes without any issue but does not fix the no boot issue.

The interesting thing is that the <CHIP>U1200</CHIP> PCH gets EXTREMELY hot. I replaced <CHIP>U1200</CHIP> from a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> donor board and the same exact issue persists, <CHIP>U1200</CHIP> gets extremely hot. T2 revive still completes without issue, but logic board still does not boot.

The cpu/gpu heat up as well but not even close to as hot as the PCH <CHIP>U1200</CHIP>.

Any idea why the PCH is getting so hot? Seems like it is likely related to the problem in some way. Is this possibly a bad CPU causing it to get super hot?

Any ideas/troubleshooting would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> // Will not startup // <CHIP>U1200</CHIP> extreme heat
threads.message: Compare diode mode readings around PCH with good board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> // Will not startup // <CHIP>U1200</CHIP> extreme heat
threads.message: All diode readings precisely match the good board around the PCH. CPU vcore is stable and present as well.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> // Will not startup // <CHIP>U1200</CHIP> extreme heat
threads.message: Check all PCH power rails, pages 16 & 17.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> // Will not startup // <CHIP>U1200</CHIP> extreme heat
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.38V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5</SIGNAL> - 1.79V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_PRIM</SIGNAL> - 1.03V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_PRIM_PCH_VCCAXTAL_F</SIGNAL> - 1.03V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_PRIM_PCH_VCCAPLL_F</SIGNAL> - 1.03V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S5_PCH_VCCDSW</SIGNAL> - 1.03V
<SIGNAL>PPVCCSPI_PRIM_PCH</SIGNAL> - 3.33V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0_PCH_VCCHDA_F</SIGNAL> - 1.79V
<SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> - 3.0V
<SIGNAL>PPDCPRTC_PCH</SIGNAL> - 1.51V
<SIGNAL>PP1V24_S5_PCH_VCCDPHY</SIGNAL> - Dropping from 0.8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_PCH_VCCPHYLDO</SIGNAL> - 1.87V
PP1V_PRIM_PCH_VCCAMPHYPLL_F - 1.03V then starts jumping around (always below 1.03V)

I think I tested all rails on those 2 pages.

I appreciate your help, thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> // Will not startup // <CHIP>U1200</CHIP> extreme heat
threads.message:
If no important data, then try restore option into DFU.

Do you note any changes on L7211 voltage, in the first 10-15s?
Check for USB activity.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> // Will not startup // <CHIP>U1200</CHIP> extreme heat
threads.message:
L7211 is very stable at .95V

Unfortunately I can't restore the T2 as the data is very important.

Apologies, but when you say check for USB activity, what do you mean?

Thanks :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> // Will not startup // <CHIP>U1200</CHIP> extreme heat
threads.message:
